G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, thereby conferring subject-matter jurisdiction on the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3 and G.L. c. 231, § 1.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, thereby conferring subject-matter jurisdiction on the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3 and G.L. c. 231, § 1.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 8, because the cause of action arose within Middlesex County and, upon information and belief, Defendant resides in Middlesex County.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly states a general principle of Massachusetts tort law that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, grounded in foreseeability. While the rest of the opinion applies that principle to the specific firearm-storage facts, the quoted general rule directly supports the proposition about Massachusetts common-law duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

*Muise v. Romney*, 385 Mass. 108, 110 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
*Muise v. Romney*, 385 Mass. 108, 110 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses landlord duties arising from the implied warranty of habitability, the State Sanitary Code, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and statutory duties under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It also expressly declines to decide the scope of liability for negligently inflicted emotional distress. Nowhere does the court state or rely on a broad Massachusetts common-law principle that every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others; the duty analysis is specific to landlords and statutory/contractual obligations. Thus the case does not provide authority for the general duty proposition cited.
*Muise v. Romney*, 385 Mass. 108, 110 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Gem’s legal responsibility, however, depends on the duties it owed to Solomon, and Gem’s arguments concerning plumbing misstate the scope of a landlord’s duty to its tenants. We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition… Further, a landlord that fails to maintain a habitable dwelling for its tenant is liable for resulting personal injuries, at least when the landlord has failed to exercise reasonable care in maintenance.”

*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the control, supervision, and restraint of his Dog in a public park, so as to avoid creating an unreasonable risk of bodily harm to persons lawfully using the park, including joggers such as Plaintiff.
*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns a storeowner’s duty to customers bitten by a dog inside a department store, not an individual dog owner’s duty to control his own dog in a public park. The court assumes only a premises-liability duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the store safe from harm caused by animals and ultimately holds no liability absent foreseeability or knowledge of dangerous propensities. It does not recognize or discuss any independent duty of a dog owner to control, supervise, or restrain his dog in a public place like a park, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff can recover only upon proof of breach of the defendant’s duty to keep the premises in safe condition for her use as a customer. Reasonable care to keep the premises safe for customers from harm caused by animals is within the scope of this duty… The action is grounded upon negligence, but there was no negligence unless the plaintiff’s injury… was in its general nature a probable consequence of some act or omission for which the defendant was responsible.”

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 173.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to comply with applicable statutes, ordinances, and park regulations requiring dogs to be kept on a leash within Newton Commonwealth Park.

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: Defendant’s violation of the park’s leash rules and applicable municipal dog control regulations is evidence of negligence and supports a finding that Defendant breached his duty of care.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The case does address the role of statutory or regulatory violations in negligence, but it does so to reaffirm that such violations are only "some evidence" of negligence and do not themselves establish breach of duty. The court emphasizes that violation of a statute does not constitute negligence per se and that the jury may still find no negligence despite a proven violation. Thus, while conceptually similar, Bennett does not positively support the proposition; it limits the effect of such violations rather than endorsing them as sufficient proof of a breach of duty.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: "It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only 'some evidence' of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent."

*Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.*,.proposition: Defendant’s violation of the park’s leash rules and applicable municipal dog control regulations is evidence of negligence and supports a finding that Defendant breached his duty of care.
*Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with violation of fire-prevention regulations governing disposal of highly inflammable motion picture film, not leash rules or municipal dog control regulations. It does stand for the general principle that violation of a statute or regulation is evidence of negligence, but it is unrelated to animals or parks and thus cannot properly be cited as authority for the specific dog‑leash proposition stated. The proposition misdescribes the subject matter of the case.
*Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.*,.relevant_excerpt: “The regulations have the force and effect of law. A violation of a statute, ordinance or regulation, although not conclusive, is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent. Wright v. Malden & Melrose Railroad, 4 Allen, 283, 290. Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 140. … Gordon v. Bedard, 265 Mass. 408, 411.”

*Oliveria v. Nat\u2019l Amusements, Inc..proposition: Defendant’s conduct constituted a failure to act as a reasonably prudent dog owner would act under the same or similar circumstances.
*Oliveria v. Nat\u2019l Amusements, Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns medical malpractice and the loss-of-chance doctrine in a wrongful death action involving delayed diagnosis of breast cancer. It does not involve animals, dog ownership, or any standard of care for dog owners. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for whether a defendant failed to act as a reasonably prudent dog owner under similar circumstances.

*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable that a large, barking, off-leash dog charging toward a jogger could cause the jogger to take sudden evasive action and suffer injury as a result.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns foreseeability of harm from an unsecured forklift being operated by an unauthorized, intoxicated seaman, not from a dog or an animal’s behavior. While it discusses general foreseeability principles (including that certain third-party misuse of dangerous instrumentalities can be anticipated), it never addresses animals, dogs, or a victim’s evasive reaction to a charging dog. Using this case to support the specific proposition about a barking, off-leash dog causing a jogger to take evasive action misapplies the holding and context.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable. The authority had specific procedures for securing the forklifts… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons… It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area…”

*Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.*, 319 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a negligent actor is liable for harm that results from a foreseeable reaction or response to the danger created by the actor’s negligence.
*Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.*, 319 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on duty, privity, and manufacturer liability to remote vendees; it does not address liability for injuries resulting from a third party’s reaction or response to a danger created by the defendant. The discussion of foreseeability is about anticipating injury to ultimate consumers and intervening/superseding causes, not about a victim’s responsive or protective conduct as a link in the causal chain. Thus, it does not establish the specific principle that a negligent actor is liable for harm resulting from a foreseeable reaction to the created danger.
*Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd.*, 319 Mas.relevant_excerpt: Still another is that the causal relation of a manufacturer’s negligence to the injury may be broken by the intervention of a superseding cause … such as some negligence or fault of another, whereby the manufacturer’s negligence ceases to be the proximate cause of the injury. In the present case no evidence of any superseding cause appears. … But even where there is some intervening negligence of another, that may not constitute a superseding cause if it could have been foreseen.

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s negligence and fall within the scope of the risk created by allowing a large dog to run off-leash in a public park.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the injuries were a natural and probable (i.e., foreseeable) consequence within the scope of the risk. Thus, this citation undermines rather than supports the stated proposition.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages include past and future medical expenses, lost wages and/or diminished earning capacity, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, emotional distress, and all other damages allowed under Massachusetts law for personal injury caused by negligence. See G.L. c. 231, § 6B; *Conley v. Moran*, 349 Mass. 311, 316 (1965).

*Conley v. Moran*, 349 Mass. 311, 316 (1.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages include past and future medical expenses, lost wages and/or diminished earning capacity, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, emotional distress, and all other damages allowed under Massachusetts law for personal injury caused by negligence. See G.L. c. 231, § 6B; *Conley v. Moran*, 349 Mass. 311, 316 (1965).
*Conley v. Moran*, 349 Mass. 311, 316 (1.case_name: Old Colony Trust Co. v. New England Merchants National Bank
*Conley v. Moran*, 349 Mass. 311, 316 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Conley v. Moran is a will-construction and trust-distribution case; it does not involve a negligence or personal injury action, nor does it discuss categories of tort damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or emotional distress. The pages provided concern interpretation of testamentary provisions and trustee discretion, not damages under G.L. c. 231, § 6B. Accordingly, this case does not support the proposition about the scope of recoverable personal injury damages in Massachusetts.
*Conley v. Moran*, 349 Mass. 311, 316 (1.relevant_excerpt: The trustee under the will of Louis S. Ross (the testator) seeks instructions concerning the final distribution of the trust fund created under art. Second of the will. Several respondents have appealed from a decree of the Probate Court, later described.... 7. The decree of the Probate Court is to be modified to apply to the accumulated income (as well as the principal) of the trust fund and to permit Longden’s executrix to share in the distribution of thirty per cent of the trust fund and in fifty-five per cent of the trust together with the other persons named in that decree as so sharing.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: In any event, under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any alleged comparative negligence on the part of Plaintiff would not bar recovery but would only proportionately reduce damages, provided that Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was not greater than the total negligence of Defendant.

*Hanlon v. Town of Southborough*, 381 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff’s reaction was that of a reasonable person confronted with a sudden emergency not of her own making, and such conduct does not constitute negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Hanlon v. Town of Southborough*, 381 Ma.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is from a criminal case involving murder, evidentiary issues, Brady material, and sentencing. It does not discuss civil negligence standards, the conduct of a plaintiff, or the Massachusetts ‘sudden emergency’ doctrine. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition that a plaintiff’s reasonable reaction to a sudden emergency not of her own making is non‑negligent under Massachusetts law.
*Hanlon v. Town of Southborough*, 381 Ma.relevant_excerpt: No portion of the quoted opinion addresses negligence, reasonable person standards in emergencies, or civil liability. The case concerns criminal convictions for murder, evidentiary disclosure obligations under Brady and Agurs, cross-examination limits, and sentencing, not tort principles.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff her allowable costs of suit pursuant to G.L. c. 261;
